title: Fig Farming in the North Central Region with Kris Heeter

tasks.task: Conducting a project on growing cold-hardy fig varieties in the Midwest.
subtasks: Researching and selecting cold-hardy fig varieties (Chicago Hardy, Syrian Dark, Abu George).
Planting fig trees in ground and in pots on three different farms.
Winterizing in-ground figs using a cordon system and straw mulching.
Winterizing potted figs in protected storage areas.
Training fig trees using the cordon system to reduce frost damage risk.
Experimenting with living mulches or secondary crops under fig trees.
Evaluating water requirements and soil amendments for fig growth.
Monitoring for pests and diseases, especially in the first season.
Propagating fig trees through hardwood cuttings.
Exploring value-added products from figs (jams, teas, sap utilization).

tasks.task: Growing cold-hardy figs in pots and ground.
subtasks: Planting 1-year-old fig trees in 10-gallon pots in early August.
Watering and mulching potted figs weekly as needed.
Transferring potted figs to indoor storage for winter protection.
Monitoring potted figs' growth and dormancy.

tasks.task: Cold-hardy fig cultivation in the Midwest.
subtasks: Overwintering techniques for in-ground figs (using straw mulch and cordon system).
Adjusting soil amendments and mulching methods based on initial success.
Conducting soil tests for optimal growing conditions.
Training fig canes horizontally in the cordon system to enhance survival.
Observing and documenting fig growth, potential pests, and diseases.
Creating jams from both ripe and unripe figs.
Developing tea products from fig leaves.
Contacting local herbalists and wellness practitioners to assess market interest.
Sharing project findings with local farming associations and organizations.
